linkTarget.anchoringText: Core data also indicate that there is a tidal influence in some of the thicker sandstone bodies, particularly in their upper portions. Prior interpretations include a distributary channel origin (Young et al., 1991) and poinnt bar deposition associated with a meandering fluvial channel (Smith et al., 1995). As with th 34-1 sand, the 33-series reservoir occurs interbedded with mudstone and thin carbonates. (Carter et al., 2003). The 33 Series in the WW B-10 core comprises a fine-grained sandstone body containing mudstone clasts, carbonaceous laminae and flaser bedding (Figure 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: WW B-10 facies analysis from Core Data

formatted-caption.caption-text: WW B-10 facies analysis from Core Data

linkTarget.anchoringText: Reservoir characterization in Widuri field is complicated by complex lithology and difficulties in predicting changes in fluid distribution. 33-S Sand body is interpreted as complex channel compartmentalized and part of waterflood project associated with distributary channels, mouth bars and delta front shoal (Figure 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: 33-6 (attribute, depth structure and netsand) Map

formatted-caption.caption-text: 33-6 (attribute, depth structure and netsand) Map

linkTarget.anchoringText: The 34-3 is not the primary reservoir since the distribution of this sand reservoir is not widespread and include in the 34-series package. This sand interpreted as mainly intertidal, estuarine succession that is locally supratidal freswater within the uppermost part of the section (Figure 3). This reservoirs is porous an permeable with average 26.7% and 3720 md, unconsolidated, quartztose sandstone, moderately sorted, fine grained sand with mainly subrounded to rounded framework grains.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: 34-S attribute and facies Map

formatted-caption.caption-text: 34-S attribute and facies Map

linkTarget.anchoringText: Flattened horizon (Yellow) has been done to determine the sedimentation process for 35-1 reservoir. (Figure 4). 35-1 reservoir divided into two blocks, East and West block. 35-1 east has very thick sand and strong water drive mechanism meanwhile 35-1 west is thin sand reservoir with solution gas drive reservoir. Challenge for this reservoir is about low recovery of reserve at 35-1 due to distribution sand issue.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Seismic Attribute Map of 35-1 Sand flattened at Yellow Horizon (Coal A)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Seismic Attribute Map of 35-1 Sand flattened at Yellow Horizon (Coal A)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Sedimentation is controlled by strike-slip fault which trend relatively N – S direction, indicated by positive flower structure and abrupt reflection thickness (reservoir thickness) in the west and east part of WW Field (Figure 5). The hypothetical thin reservoir of 35-series interval is associate to crevasse splay deposit, which controlled by channel sinuosity. The more sinuous channel is more probable to have crevasse splay deposit v.v

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Isochrone Map of 35 Series Sand atWIDD-29 area

formatted-caption.caption-text: Isochrone Map of 35 Series Sand atWIDD-29 area

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Isochrone Map of whole 35-1 Sand

formatted-caption.caption-text: Isochrone Map of whole 35-1 Sand

linkTarget.anchoringText: First production of this well was 4,824 BOPD, 22% WC, 394 mcfd. Several pump repair was done during production life to maintain production from this reservoir. Since the energy of this reservoir is limited, in year 2011 WW D-49i was completed as injector to support WW D-29 as peer water injection. Figure 7,Figure 8 showed the depth structure and nett sand of 35-1 sandstone Talang Akar Reservoir, while Figure 9 showed the cross section between WW D-29 and WW D-49i.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Depth Structure 35-1 TAF Sand

formatted-caption.caption-text: Depth Structure 35-1 TAF Sand

linkTarget.anchoringText: First production of this well was 4,824 BOPD, 22% WC, 394 mcfd. Several pump repair was done during production life to maintain production from this reservoir. Since the energy of this reservoir is limited, in year 2011 WW D-49i was completed as injector to support WW D-29 as peer water injection. Figure 7,Figure 8 showed the depth structure and nett sand of 35-1 sandstone Talang Akar Reservoir, while Figure 9 showed the cross section between WW D-29 and WW D-49i.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Cross Section WW D-29 and WW D-49i

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross Section WW D-29 and WW D-49i

linkTarget.anchoringText: To maintain the production of the well, several well intervention especially change the ESP was done. In April 2014, there was increasing water cut phenomenon after this job happen. Average water cut before pump repair job was 84% WC (154 bopd, 982 bfpd), and average water cut after pump repair job was 91.5% WC 25 bopd, 1233 bfpd). This condition made the production of this well decrease about 125 bopd (Figure 10). The low oil production was keep maintaining until 2016 before the well got DHP (Down Hole Problem).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Production and Injection of WW D-29 and WW D-49i

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production and Injection of WW D-29 and WW D-49i

linkTarget.anchoringText: Looking at the well criteria selection, this well was one of the candidates for modified completion fluid treatment since the wellbore of WW D-29 was also did not have any mechanical restriction. This well was completed cased hole completion with open hole horizontal (440 ft) using Excluder screen in the main production reservoir 35-1 sand (Figure 11).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Wellbore schematic of WW D-29

formatted-caption.caption-text: Wellbore schematic of WW D-29

linkTarget.anchoringText: The First production of this well in June 2005 was 312 bopd, 20% WC, 1 Mcfd. In year 2009 the injector well got plugged problem due to sand accumulated in the wellbore from the treated water which injected to the well, so WW B-30Si was drilled to replace WW B-30S. WW B-30S was completed in year 2014. Figure 12 and Figure 13 showed the depth structure map and nett sand map of 33-6 sand Talang Akar Formation, while Figure 14 showed the cross section of producers and injector in 33-6 Sand Talang Akar Formation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Depth structure map of 33-6 Sand TAF

formatted-caption.caption-text: Depth structure map of 33-6 Sand TAF

In year 2009 the injector well got plugged problem due to sand accumulated in the wellbore from the treated water which injected to the well, so WW B-30Si was drilled to replace WW B-30S. WW B-30S was completed in year 2014. Figure 12 and Figure 13 showed the depth structure map and nett sand map of 33-6 sand Talang Akar Formation, while Figure 14 showed the cross section of producers and injector in 33-6 Sand Talang Akar Formation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The First production of this well in June 2005 was 312 bopd, 20% WC, 1 Mcfd. In year 2009 the injector well got plugged problem due to sand accumulated in the wellbore from the treated water which injected to the well, so WW B-30Si was drilled to replace WW B-30S. WW B-30S was completed in year 2014. Figure 12 and Figure 13 showed the depth structure map and nett sand map of 33-6 sand Talang Akar Formation, while Figure 14 showed the cross section of producers and injector in 33-6 Sand Talang Akar Formation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross section producers and injector of 33-6 Sand TAF

linkTarget.anchoringText: The well was shut in for about 7 years due to low potential based on the last oil rate. When the well was reactivated in year 2015, the water cut was increase from 40 %WC, 49 bopd (last rate on Dec 2007) to 95.4%, 20 bopd (rate on March 2015). One of the reason why the water cut increase is because of the offset producer still producing oil. Production plot of WW H-12 can be showed in Figure 15. The wellbore of WW H-12 was also did not have any mechanical restriction. This well was completed cased hole completion with perforation interval (66 ft) using gravel pack in the main production reservoir 33-6 sand (Figure 16).

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Production plot WW H-12 and WW B-30i

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production plot WW H-12 and WW B-30i

linkTarget.anchoringText: The well was shut in for about 7 years due to low potential based on the last oil rate. When the well was reactivated in year 2015, the water cut was increase from 40 %WC, 49 bopd (last rate on Dec 2007) to 95.4%, 20 bopd (rate on March 2015). One of the reason why the water cut increase is because of the offset producer still producing oil. Production plot of WW H-12 can be showed in Figure 15. The wellbore of WW H-12 was also did not have any mechanical restriction. This well was completed cased hole completion with perforation interval (66 ft) using gravel pack in the main production reservoir 33-6 sand (Figure 16).

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Wellbore Schematic of WW H-12

formatted-caption.caption-text: Wellbore Schematic of WW H-12

linkTarget.anchoringText: Well II A-22 was completed in 34-3 Sand in July 2007 with cased hole completion, the sand control of this well is using screen hanging on the ESP, so the fine sand will not pass the intake of the ESP but settling down to the rat hole. II A-22 was the only well producing in the 34-3 compartement (Figure 17). The thichkest sand in 34-3 reservoir is penetrated in this sand, it can be seen in the cross section in Figure 18.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Depth Strucure Map 34-3 Talang Akar Formation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Depth Strucure Map 34-3 Talang Akar Formation

linkTarget.anchoringText: Well II A-22 was completed in 34-3 Sand in July 2007 with cased hole completion, the sand control of this well is using screen hanging on the ESP, so the fine sand will not pass the intake of the ESP but settling down to the rat hole. II A-22 was the only well producing in the 34-3 compartement (Figure 17). The thichkest sand in 34-3 reservoir is penetrated in this sand, it can be seen in the cross section in Figure 18.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Cross Section 34-3 Talang Akar Formation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross Section 34-3 Talang Akar Formation

linkTarget.anchoringText: The production profile of this well could be seen in Figure 19. From the wellbore restriction side, this well also did not have a problem, Last clean out operation by sand bailer was done and able to bail out sand until 4555 ft MD. Meanwhile perforation interval is at 4480-4510 ft MD (Figure 20)

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Production Plot II A-22

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production Plot II A-22

linkTarget.anchoringText: The production profile of this well could be seen in Figure 19. From the wellbore restriction side, this well also did not have a problem, Last clean out operation by sand bailer was done and able to bail out sand until 4555 ft MD. Meanwhile perforation interval is at 4480-4510 ft MD (Figure 20)

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Wellbore schematic of II A-22

formatted-caption.caption-text: Wellbore schematic of II A-22

linkTarget.anchoringText: After evaluating the productivity of the well, upsizing the ESP is an opportunity to increase the production fluid, so the ESP was change from Q10 with capacity range 600 – 1250 bfpd to Q20 with capacity range 1150 – 2050 bfpd. With both combination of increasing fluid rate and decreasing water cut, WW D-29 become successful pilot project. The water cut was decrease form 98% to 83% in the lowest water cut, then sustain in 92%WC. We can see the chart of increasing oil production both from increasing fluid production and decreasing water cut in Figure 21 and Figure 22.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: Production Well Test of WW D-29 Before and After Treatment

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production Well Test of WW D-29 Before and After Treatment

linkTarget.anchoringText: After evaluating the productivity of the well, upsizing the ESP is an opportunity to increase the production fluid, so the ESP was change from Q10 with capacity range 600 – 1250 bfpd to Q20 with capacity range 1150 – 2050 bfpd. With both combination of increasing fluid rate and decreasing water cut, WW D-29 become successful pilot project. The water cut was decrease form 98% to 83% in the lowest water cut, then sustain in 92%WC. We can see the chart of increasing oil production both from increasing fluid production and decreasing water cut in Figure 21 and Figure 22.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Water Cut Profile of WW D-29

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water Cut Profile of WW D-29

linkTarget.anchoringText: The treatment was done in August 3, 2016 to replace the ESP which has been down due to electrical problem. Motor burn out was found when workover rig pulling whole ESP string. Changing ESP from Q-05 (capacity 200-650 bfpd) to Q08 (capacity 400 – 1050 bfpd) was choosen due to higher efficiency. After the treatment the water cut was decreasing from 80% to 34% in the lowest water cut and maintain in 70% WC. The chart can be showed in Figure 23 and Figure 24.

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Production Well Test of WW H-12 Before and After Treatment

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production Well Test of WW H-12 Before and After Treatment

linkTarget.anchoringText: The treatment was done in August 3, 2016 to replace the ESP which has been down due to electrical problem. Motor burn out was found when workover rig pulling whole ESP string. Changing ESP from Q-05 (capacity 200-650 bfpd) to Q08 (capacity 400 – 1050 bfpd) was choosen due to higher efficiency. After the treatment the water cut was decreasing from 80% to 34% in the lowest water cut and maintain in 70% WC. The chart can be showed in Figure 23 and Figure 24.

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: Water Cut Profile of WW H-12

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water Cut Profile of WW H-12

linkTarget.anchoringText: Since the well was shut in for more than 3 years, this job was categorized as reactivation. The treatment was done in October 2016 to install the ESP for producing the well. After the treatment the water cut was decreasing from 96% to 75% in the lowest water cut and maintain in 82% WC. The chart can be showed in Figure 25 and Figure 26.

image-wrap.label: Figure 25
image-wrap.caption: Production Well Test of II A-22 Before and After Treatment

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production Well Test of II A-22 Before and After Treatment
